application.name: basesystem
application.summary: The skeleton package which defines a simple Fedora system
application.description: Basesystem defines the components of a basic Fedora system (for example, the package installation order to use during bootstrapping). Basesystem should be in every installation of a system, and it should never be removed.

application.name: bash
application.description: The GNU Bourne Again shell (Bash) is a shell or command language interpreter that is compatible with the Bourne shell (sh). Bash incorporates useful features from the Korn shell (ksh) and the C shell (csh). Most sh scripts can be run by bash without modification.

application.name: fedora-gpg-keys
application.description: This package provides the RPM signature keys.

application.name: fedora-release
application.description: Fedora release files such as various /etc/ files that define the release and systemd preset files that determine which services are enabled by default.

application.name: fedora-release-common
application.description: Release files common to all Editions and Spins of Fedora

application.name: fedora-release-identity-basic
application.summary: Package providing the basic Fedora identity
application.description: Provides the necessary files for a Fedora installation that is not identifying itself as a particular Edition or Spin.

application.name: fedora-repos
application.description: Fedora package repository files for yum and dnf along with gpg public keys.

application.name: filesystem
application.summary: The basic directory layout for a Linux system
application.description: The filesystem package is one of the basic packages that is installed on a Linux system. Filesystem contains the basic directory layout for a Linux operating system, including the correct permissions for the directories.

application.name: glibc
application.description: The glibc package contains standard libraries which are used by multiple programs on the system. In order to save disk space and memory, as well as to make upgrading easier, common system code is kept in one place and shared between programs. This particular package contains the most important sets of shared libraries: the standard C library and the standard math library. Without these two libraries, a Linux system will not function.

application.name: glibc-common
application.summary: Common binaries and locale data for glibc
application.description: The glibc-common package includes common binaries for the GNU libc libraries, as well as national language (locale) support.

application.name: libgcc
application.description: This package contains GCC shared support library which is needed e.g. for exception handling support.

application.name: ncurses-base
application.description: This package contains descriptions of common terminals. Other terminal descriptions are included in the ncurses-term package.

application.name: ncurses-libs
application.description:
The curses library routines are a terminal-independent method of updating character screens with reasonable optimization. The ncurses (new curses) library is a freely distributable replacement for the discontinued 4.4 BSD classic curses library.
This package contains the ncurses libraries.

application.name: setup
application.summary: A set of system configuration and setup files
application.description: The setup package contains a set of important system configuration and setup files, such as passwd, group, and profile.

application.name: tzdata
application.description: This package contains data files with rules for various timezones around the world.
